overallGoal: Master the fundamental concepts of Convection Heat Transfer, focusing on Boundary Layer Fundamentals, Dimensionless Parameters, and Analogies.

keyConcepts.explanation: Covers velocity, thermal, and concentration boundary layers, including laminar vs turbulent flow characteristics and boundary layer thickness relationships.
Includes Reynolds, Prandtl, Schmidt, and Nusselt numbers, which are crucial for scaling and similarity analysis in convection problems.
Includes heat-mass transfer analogy, Reynolds analogy, and Chilton-Colburn analogies that relate different transport phenomena.

generalTips: Sketch boundary layer profiles for different fluids to visualize concepts.
Always identify boundary layer type, relevant dimensionless parameters, and applicable analogies before solving problems.
Use mnemonic devices to remember common Prandtl numbers (e.g., 'Gases~1, Water~10, Oils>100, Liquid metals<<1').

keyFormulas.description: Dimensionless quantity that predicts flow patterns in different fluid flow situations.
keyFormulas.usage_context: Used to determine whether flow is laminar or turbulent. Critical for boundary layer analysis.

keyFormulas.description: Ratio of momentum diffusivity to thermal diffusivity.
keyFormulas.usage_context: Important for determining relative thickness of velocity vs thermal boundary layers.

keyFormulas.description: Ratio of convective to conductive heat transfer at a boundary.
keyFormulas.usage_context: Used to calculate convection heat transfer coefficients in forced convection problems.
Central to Reynolds analogy, relating friction factor to heat transfer.

keyFormulas.description: Modified Reynolds analogy for heat and mass transfer.
keyFormulas.usage_context: Used when Pr ≠ 1 to relate skin friction to heat transfer coefficient.

keyFormulas.description: Approximate thickness of velocity boundary layer for laminar flow.
keyFormulas.usage_context: Flat plate laminar flow calculations, valid for Re < 5×10^5.
